passage:
(1) On July 20, 1969, humans accomplished one of the most remarkable achievements in history – landing on the surface of the moon. The Apollo 11 mission, commanded by Neil Armstrong, along with Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins, marked the culmination of years of scientific research, technological innovation, and human determination. This event not only demonstrated what humans could achieve through cooperation and perseverance but also changed how we view our place in the universe.

(2) The journey to the moon began when President John F. Kennedy declared in 1961 that the United States would land a man on the moon before the end of the decade. This ambitious goal required the development of new technologies, spacecrafts, and equipment that had never been created before. Thousands of scientists, engineers, and technicians worked tirelessly to design and build the rockets, command modules, and lunar landing modules necessary for the mission.

(3) After launching from Earth on July 16, 1969, the Apollo 11 spacecraft traveled for three days before entering lunar orbit. On July 20, Armstrong and Aldrin boarded the lunar module 'Eagle' and separated from the command module 'Columbia,' where Collins remained. As the Eagle descended toward the lunar surface, Armstrong had to manually guide the module past a field of boulders to find a safe landing spot, while fuel supplies were running dangerously low.

(4) At 20:17 UTC, Armstrong's voice crackled through the radio: "Houston, Tranquility Base here. The Eagle has landed." Hours later, Armstrong became the first human to step onto the lunar surface, uttering the famous words: "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind." Aldrin joined him shortly after, and together they spent about two and a half hours collecting samples, taking photographs, and setting up experiments on the moon's surface.

(5) The successful moon landing changed how humanity saw itself and what we believed was possible. More than 600 million people – about one-fifth of the world's population at the time – watched the historic broadcast. The mission demonstrated the incredible potential of human ingenuity and cooperation. The footprints left by Armstrong and Aldrin still remain on the moon's surface today, preserved in the lunar dust where there is no wind to erase them – a lasting testament to this remarkable human achievement.

questions.question: Which tense should be used to fill the blank? She _____ to Paris three times in her life.
Choose the correct option to complete the sentence: If it _____ tomorrow, we'll cancel the picnic.
Select the grammatically correct sentence:

options.A: Neither the students nor the teacher are ready.
options.B: Neither the students nor the teacher is ready.
options.C: Neither the students nor the teacher be ready.
options.D: Neither the students nor the teacher have been ready.

questions.question: Choose the correct passive form: They build new houses in this area every year.

options.A: New houses are building in this area every year.
options.B: New houses are being built in this area every year.
options.C: New houses have been built in this area every year.
options.D: New houses built in this area every year.

options.A: You must to arrive before 9 PM.
options.C: They might be late for dinner.

options.B: They went to the Europe for their honeymoon.

options.D: He is best player in the team.

options.A: Yesterday went we to the beach.

options.B: They have known each other for a long time.
options.C: I haven't seen him since last Monday.

options.A: A type of clothing worn for special occasions

options.A: That the Apollo 11 mission would be launched
options.B: That humans would land on the moon before the end of the decade
options.C: That Neil Armstrong would be the first person on the moon
options.D: That the United States would build the Eagle lunar module

options.B: About two and a half hours

options.A: To explain the scientific benefits of the moon landing

options.D: To detail the technical aspects of spacecraft design
